column1: Adverbs: inte heller — When do you use 'inte heller'?
column2:
Use 'inte heller' after a negation to agree with it ('… neither / … not either'); not 'inte också'.
Hon kommer inte. Han kommer inte heller.

column1: Adverbs: också / inte heller — Where does 'inte heller' go in a full main clause?
column2:
In Box 4 (Same position as 'inte').
Jag är inte heller trött

column1: Adverbs: också / inte heller — What is the short reply for “I don’t either / me neither”?
column2:
Use the fixed phrase 'Inte jag heller.' (no verb).
– Jag har ingen katt. – Inte jag heller.

column1: Adverbs: också / inte heller — What happens after 'inte heller' if the first clause had 'ingen/inget/inga'?
column2:
Switch to 'någon'/'något'/'några' (avoid the negative forms).
Vi har inga äpplen. De har inte heller några äpplen.

column1: Conjunctions: What do coordinating conjunctions do, and do they change word order?
column2:
They join same-type units (words, phrases, main clauses) and keep normal word order.
Jag lagar mat och han diskar.

column1: Conjunctions: What does 'eller' mean and how is it used?
column2:
Alternative/choice ('or').
Vi lagar mat eller beställer pizza.

column1: Conjunctions: What does 'men' mean and how is it used?
column2:
Contrast ('but').
Hon vill resa men hon har inte tid.

column1: Conjunctions: What does 'för' mean and how is it used?
column2:
Reason/cause ('for/because', slightly formal).
Jag går hem, för jag är trött.

column1: Conjunctions: What does 'så' mean?
column2:
Consequence/result ('so').
Det regnade, så vi stannade hemma.

column1: Conjunctions: When may you drop the subject after 'och/men' in clause 2?
column2:
Only when the subject would come right after the conjunction and is the same as in clause 1.
Anna gick hem och somnade direkt.

column1: Conjunctions: When must you keep the subject after 'och/men'?
column2:
1) If any other element is in Box 1, the subject must be in box 3.
… och i dag somnade hon direkt.
2) If the subject changes in clause 2, you must state it.
Anna gick hem men Peter stannade kvar.

column1: Nouns (indefinite, no article): Explain article use when stating someone’s job/religion/political view.
column2:
No article for the label; if an adjective is added, use ‘en/ett’.
‘Petra’ är ‘läkare’. / ‘Petra’ är ‘en duktig läkare’.

column1: Nouns (indefinite, no article): Explain article use after a possessive or a genitive (e.g., ‘Anna’s’).
column2:
Keep the noun without an article after genitives/possessives.
‘Annas vänner’ ger henne råd.

column1: Nouns (indefinite, no article): Explain article use after ‘nästa’ and ‘samma’.
column2:
Keep the noun without an article after ‘nästa’/‘samma’.
‘Nästa sommar’ gör vi ‘samma sak’.

column1: Nouns (indefinite, no article): Explain article use with substances and uncountables.
column2:
No article with substances/uncountables.
Jag gillar ‘öl’.

column1: Nouns (indefinite, no article): Explain article use after ‘ingen/inget/inga’, ‘någon/något/några’, ‘flera’, and numbers.
column2:
No article after these quantifiers; often none after numbers.
Hon har ‘några relationer’, ‘ett par dejter’.

column1: Nouns (indefinite with article): Explain when to use ‘en/ett’ for new information.
column2:
Use ‘en/ett’ to introduce new/first-mentioned items.
‘Anna’ lånade ‘en hund’.

column1: Nouns (indefinite with article): Explain ‘en/ett’ when identity is unimportant (‘any’).
column2:
Use ‘en/ett’ when any instance is fine, not a specific one.
Jag vill ha ‘en frukt’.

column1: Nouns (definite): Explain the second-mention rule.
column2:
Use the definite on second mention of a referent.
… lämnade tillbaka ‘hunden’.

column1: Nouns (definite): Explain the part/association rule after a mentioned whole.
column2:
Make parts/associated items definite once the whole is mentioned.
‘Trädgården’ är jättestor.

column1: Nouns (definite): Explain use with unique/well-known referents.
column2:
Use the definite for unique/known entities.
‘Statsministern’ … ‘slottet’.

column1: Nouns (definite): Explain body parts/possessions vs possessives.
column2:
Prefer definite form instead of possessive + noun for body parts/owned items.
Ont i ‘huvudet’; tog ‘bilen’.

column1: Nouns (definite): Explain what follows demonstratives.
column2:
Demonstratives take a definite noun.
‘den där blomman’

column1: Nouns (definite): Explain use after ordinals.
column2:
After ordinals, the noun is often definite.
‘första gången’
